name: Polymorphic Open/Closed Principle
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that states software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification, promoting the use of abstract base classes and interfaces.

name: Liskov Substitution Principle
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that ensures objects of a superclass shall be replaceable with objects of a subclass without affecting the correctness of the program.

name: Interface Segregation Principle
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that states no client should be forced to depend on methods it does not use, advocating for smaller, client-specific interfaces.

name: SOLID Principles
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A set of five principles that guide software design to make it more understandable, flexible, and maintainable.
source: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design.pdf

name: Single Responsibility Principle (SRP)
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle stating that a class should have only one reason to change, focusing on a single responsibility.

name: Open/Closed Principle (OCP)
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A design principle stating that software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architect’s Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

name: Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP)
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that states subclasses should be substitutable for their base classes without altering the correctness of the program.

name: Interface Segregation Principle (ISP)
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: Design principle that states no client should be forced to depend on methods it does not use.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architect’s Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

name: Dependency Inversion Principle (DIP)
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A design principle that suggests high-level modules should not depend on low-level modules but both should depend on abstractions.
source: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design.pdf

name: Dependency Inversion Principle
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that emphasizes the importance of depending on abstractions rather than concrete implementations to reduce coupling and enhance maintainability.

name: DRY
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A design principle aimed at reducing repetition of software patterns and promoting reusability.
source: Design It!_ From Programmer to Software Architect.pdf

name: YAGNI
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: You Aren\'t Gonna Need It principle that advises against adding functionality until it is necessary.

name: KISS
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: Keep It Simple, Stupid principle emphasizes simplicity in software design to avoid unnecessary complexity.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architect’s Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

name: GRASP

name: ØMQ Messaging Patterns

description: A set of messaging patterns like publish/subscribe and request/reply that simplify messaging architecture.

name: Transport Layer

name: SCTP

name: DCCP

name: Domain Service

name: Domain Event

name: Eventual Consistency

name: Law of Demeter
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A design principle that emphasizes minimizing knowledge of the internal structure of objects to promote loose coupling.

name: Root Entity

name: Repository

name: Context Mapping
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: A technique used to visualize and understand the relationships between different Bounded Contexts.

name: Strategic Design Patterns
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: Patterns that guide the overall structure and organization of a system in Domain-Driven Design, focusing on high-level design.

name: SaaS-based Architecture

description: An architectural style that allows software to be delivered as a service over the internet, often involving multi-tenancy.

name: Scrum-based Project Management
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A structure for organizing software development processes based on Scrum methodology, facilitating iterative development.

name: Hexagonal Architecture

name: Domain-Driven Design
label:LABEL: DDDConcept

name: NoSQL Storage

name: Event Store

label:LABEL: DDDConcept

name: Read Model Projections
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Command/Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS)

name: Application Layer
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Context Map

description: A diagram that illustrates the relationships and interactions between different Bounded Contexts.

name: Domain Model

name: Adapter Pattern

name: Mutable Component

name: Map Function

name: Range Function
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Print Function

name: Clean Architecture
label:LABEL: ArchPattern

name: FinancialDataGateway
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

source: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design.pdf

name: FinancialReportRequester

name: Component Hierarchy

name: Dependency Inversion
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

name: High-Level Module (HL1)

name: Humble Object Pattern
label:LABEL: DesignPattern

name: Service Architecture
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural style that structures an application as a collection of loosely coupled services.

name: REST Interface

name: Executable File

name: Library Function

name: Zone of Uselessness

name: Component Structure

name: Volatile Component Structure

name: Top-Down Design

name: Microservice Architecture
label:LABEL: ArchPattern

label:LABEL: ArchPattern

name: Inversion of Control (IoC)
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A design principle in which the control of object creation and management is transferred from the application code to a container or framework.

name: DTOs
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Data Transfer Objects used to transfer data between layers, particularly in the context of application services.

name: EventStoreConcurrencyException
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: An exception pattern used to handle concurrency conflicts in event sourcing.

name: Conflict Resolution
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A strategy to handle conflicts that arise during concurrent updates to an aggregate.

name: Mutate Method
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A method that applies events to an aggregate to change its state based on historical events.

name: When Method
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A method that handles specific events and modifies the aggregate\'s state accordingly.

name: Apply Method
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A method that appends new events to the changes list for persistence, reflecting state changes.

name: Lambda Expression
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A concise way to represent anonymous functions, allowing for more compact and readable code.

name: Event Replication
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A design pattern for ensuring that events are replicated across different storage systems for fault tolerance.

name: Memoization
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: An optimization technique that stores the results of expensive function calls and returns the cached result when the same inputs occur again.

name: Inductive User Interface
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A design pattern that focuses on creating user interfaces that adapt to user behavior and preferences.

name: Layer Supertype
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that manages surrogate identities and optimistic concurrency versioning.

name: Domain Payload Objects
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Objects that carry data between different layers or components in a system.

name: Anticorruption Layer (ACL)
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A pattern that provides a barrier between different bounded contexts to prevent corruption of the model.

name: Publish-Subscribe pattern
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A messaging pattern where senders (publishers) do not send messages directly to specific receivers (subscribers) but instead publish messages to a channel.

name: Command-Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS)
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that separates read and write operations for a data store, allowing for more scalable and maintainable systems.

name: Principle of Least Knowledge
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A design principle that encourages reducing the number of interactions between objects to minimize dependencies and maintain system integrity.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: ProjectArchived
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: A domain event representing the archival of a project.

name: Single Responsibility
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A design principle that states a class should have only one reason to change, promoting separation of concerns.

name: Stateless Services
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: A service architecture pattern where services do not maintain any state between requests, enhancing scalability.

name: Session Facade
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A design pattern that provides a simplified interface to a set of interfaces in a subsystem, often used in EJB.

name: Smart UI Anti-Pattern
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: An anti-pattern where the user interface contains too much logic, leading to maintenance challenges.

name: Aggregate Root Entity
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: The main entity that controls access to the aggregate and ensures its invariants.

name: Immutable State
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A code structure concept where the state of an object cannot be modified after it is created, promoting functional programming principles.
source: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design.pdf

name: Proof by Induction
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A mathematical technique used to prove the correctness of algorithms, particularly in iterative processes.
source: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design.pdf

name: Divide and Conquer
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A problem-solving strategy that breaks a problem into smaller, more manageable sub-problems.
source: Software Engineering Design- Theory and Practice.pdf

name: EmployeeFacade
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A facade that delegates responsibilities to the underlying classes while keeping the interface simple.
source: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design.pdf

name: Controller Component
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

source: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design.pdf

name: Interactor Component
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Presenter Component
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: View Component
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A component that represents the user interface, displaying data to the user and capturing user input.
source: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design.pdf

name: High-Level Module
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

source: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design.pdf

name: Low-Level Module
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

source: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design.pdf

name: Transactional Memory
label:LABEL: DesignPattern

source: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design.pdf

name: Take Function
label:LABEL: DesignPattern

source: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design.pdf

name: Cohesion Principles
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

source: Clean Architecture A Craftsman's Guide to Software Structure and Design.pdf

name: Stable Abstract Interfaces
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

name: Volatile Concrete Classes

name: Function Library
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Module Management Tools
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Change Management in Components

name: Component Dependency Graph
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Acyclic Dependency
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

name: C++ Include Statements
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A code structure used in C++ to represent dependencies between classes.

name: Java Import Statements
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A code structure used in Java to represent dependencies between classes.

name: Volatile Component
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Concrete Utility Library
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: BusinessRules
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Micro-service Architecture

name: UServer Interface

name: Stability Dependency Principle (SDP)

name: FinancialReportPresenter

name: Function Call
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Customer Entity

name: Software Module

name: Entities

name: Use Cases

name: Local Process

name: ServiceBoundary

name: Language-Independent API

name: FoundFood Event

name: FellInPit Event
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: Event that triggers a change in the player\'s state, managed by the higher-level policy.

name: BufferedReader

label:LABEL: CodeStructure

label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

name: Dependency Graph
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Composite
label:LABEL: DesignPattern

name: Design Pattern
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: Abstract solutions to common design problems in software development.

name: Creational Patterns
label:LABEL: DesignPattern

name: Structural Patterns
label:LABEL: DesignPattern

name: Behavioral Patterns

name: MenuItem

name: Creational Design Patterns

name: Abstract Factory Pattern

name: Iterator Pattern

name: AbstractFactory
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A creational design pattern that provides an interface for creating families of related or dependent objects without specifying their concrete classes.

name: PROXY

name: PROTOTYPE
label:LABEL: DesignPattern

name: Principles of Software Architecture

description: Fundamental guidelines that inform the design and structure of software architecture.

name: Architectural Styles and Patterns
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Generic, reusable architectural solutions that guide software design and construction.
source: Software Engineering Design- Theory and Practice.pdf

name: System Interfaces
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Defined points of interaction between different software components or systems.

name: Major Components
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Key building blocks of a software system that define its architecture.

name: Problem Solving Framework
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A structured approach to problem-solving that can be applied during the design process.

name: Initial State
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The phase in problem-solving where problems are formulated and interpreted.

name: Operational State
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A state pattern implementation that defines behavior for the operational state of the component.
source: Software Engineering Design- Theory and Practice.pdf

name: Goal State
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The final phase in problem-solving where a solution is found and the process concludes.

name: Cohesiveness
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: The degree to which the elements within a module belong together, contributing to the clarity and maintainability of the code.

name: Software Component Interface
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Well-defined interfaces for software components that facilitate interaction and integration within the system.

name: Component Design
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Models the internal structure and behavior of components, refining logical components into fine-grained elements.
source: Software Engineering Design- Theory and Practice.pdf

name: Software Development Process
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A structured approach to software development that includes phases such as requirements, design, implementation, and testing.

name: Human-Computer Interface Design
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: Design principles applied to optimize the interface between humans and computers, influencing usability.
source: Software Engineering Design- Theory and Practice.pdf

name: Software Design Documentation
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A structured document that captures all necessary design information for software systems.

name: Operation Specification
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Details regarding the operation name, parameter types, and return types in software design.

name: Stakeholder Influence
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: The principle that design decisions must consider the needs and goals of various stakeholders, which can conflict.

name: Software Architect
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Responsible for designing the software architecture and ensuring it meets requirements.

name: Component Designer
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Focuses on detailed and construction designs, implementing software components.

name: Design Principles
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: Fundamental guidelines that help in designing software systems effectively.
source: Systems Analysis and Design in - John W. Satzinger, Robert B. Ja.pdf

name: Object-Oriented Design Patterns
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: Patterns that provide solutions to common design problems in object-oriented programming.

name: Abstraction Principle
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that guides the decomposition of systems based on behavior and data, essential for managing complexity.

name: Encapsulation Principle
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that enhances collaboration among modularized units by exposing only essential information and hiding implementation details.

name: Message Data Abstraction
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A data abstraction representing various messages with attributes like ID, content, and format, simplifying data handling.

name: Send Procedural Abstraction
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A procedural abstraction that denotes a series of operations for sending data, including connection management.

name: Coupling and Cohesion
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: Design principles that emphasize the importance of minimizing dependencies between modules (coupling) while maximizing the relatedness of functionalities within a module (cohesion).

name: Separation of Interface and Implementation
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that emphasizes the need to separate the interface of a module from its implementation to enhance flexibility and maintainability.
source: Software Engineering Design- Theory and Practice.pdf

name: Sufficiency and Completeness
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: Design principles that ensure that a system has all necessary components and functionalities to meet its requirements.

name: Functional Cohesion
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A type of cohesion where all tasks in a module contribute to a single function, indicating strong module design.

name: Structured Design
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that emphasizes decomposing software systems into independent, single-purpose modules using a top-down approach.

name: Aspect-Oriented Design
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: A method for constructing software using aspects to handle cross-cutting concerns.

name: Component-Based Design
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural style that emphasizes the design of software systems as a composition of reusable components.

name: Data Structure-Based Design
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural approach that focuses on the organization and manipulation of data structures within software systems.

name: Content Coupling
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: A type of coupling where one module directly accesses the content of another module, leading to high interdependence.

name: Heuristic Evaluation
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A usability inspection method for user interfaces that helps identify usability problems in the design.

name: User Interface Design
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: The process of creating user interfaces that facilitate interaction between users and software systems, focusing on usability and efficiency.
source: Software Engineering Design- Theory and Practice.pdf

name: Algorithm
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A step-by-step procedure or formula for solving a problem, often used in software design.

name: Heuristic
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A practical approach to problem-solving that employs a method not guaranteed to be optimal but sufficient for reaching an immediate goal.

name: Minimum coupling
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A design principle that emphasizes reducing dependencies between components to enhance modularity.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Maximum cohesion
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A design principle that encourages components to be highly focused on a single task or responsibility.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Information hiding
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A design principle that promotes encapsulation by restricting access to the internal details of a component.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Central Booking System
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The main component that manages car reservations and member interactions, central to the functionality of the car club.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Mobile Application
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The application used by members to interact with the booking system, crucial for user experience and system accessibility.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Orthogonality
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A design principle that promotes independence among components, reducing interdependencies.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Ill-Structured Problems (ISP)
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: Problems that do not have a clear solution path, requiring creative and adaptive design approaches.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Layers
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that organizes software into layers, each with specific responsibilities.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Software Services
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A design concept that focuses on creating reusable services that can be accessed over a network, promoting loose coupling and scalability.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Reusable Components
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Components that can be reused in different contexts to reduce design effort and speed up development.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Satisficing
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A decision-making strategy where a satisfactory solution is sought rather than the optimal one, often due to constraints.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Agile Methods
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural approach that emphasizes flexibility and iterative development, allowing for opportunistic design strategies.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Robustness
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: A quality attribute that refers to the ability of a software architecture to handle changes and maintain functionality.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Data-Centered Repository Architectural Style
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural style focused on a central mechanism for persistent information storage, allowing manipulation by external processing units.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Global Variables
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Variables that are accessible across multiple sub-programs, often used for data sharing but can lead to tight coupling.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Client-Server System
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern where a server provides resources or services to multiple clients, emphasizing separation of concerns.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Data-Centered Repository Style
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural style that focuses on a central knowledge base for managing information, suitable for data management systems.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Architectural Design Patterns
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Patterns that describe the overall form of a system, providing solutions to recurring design challenges.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Service-Oriented Applications
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural style that allows services to communicate over a network, promoting loose coupling and reusability.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Pipe-and-Filter Architectural Style
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that breaks a system into a series of processing steps (filters) connected by data streams (pipes).
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Call-and-Return Architectural Style
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural style where components communicate by calling each other and returning results.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Broker
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Used to structure the interaction of distributed systems with highly decoupled components.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Data Flow Diagram (DFD)
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A visual representation used to model the flow of data within a system, emphasizing the transfer of information rather than the form of data.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Data-Centric Application
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural style focused on the management and processing of data, often utilizing data flow diagrams for modeling.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Entity-Relationship Diagram
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: A diagram that models the relationships between entities in a system, foundational for data modeling.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Attribute
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: A property or characteristic of an entity, used to define its data structure.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: STT (State Transition Table)
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A table used to model the states and transitions of a system, aiding in verification and validation.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: State Transition Diagram
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A diagram that models the states of an entity and the transitions between those states, useful for behavioral modeling.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Transition Condition
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: Conditions that must be met for a transition to occur, important for defining state changes.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Transition Action
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: Actions that may occur as a result of a state transition, providing insight into the behavior of the system.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Data-Flow Diagram (DFD)
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A diagram that represents the flow of data within a system, showing how data moves between processes and data stores.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Entity-Relationship Diagram (ERD)
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A diagram that shows the relationships between entities in a database, crucial for domain modeling.
source: Systems Analysis and Design in - John W. Satzinger, Robert B. Ja.pdf

name: State Transition Diagram (STD)
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A behavioral diagram that models the states of an entity or system and transitions between those states.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Finite-State Machine
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A design pattern used to manage states and transitions in systems, relevant for the packet sniffer\'s operation.
source: The Architecture of Open Source Applications 2.pdf

name: Library Component
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A reusable piece of code that provides specific functionality, often abstracted for ease of use.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Coupling Between Objects (CBO)
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: A metric indicating the degree of interdependence between classes, affecting modularity and reuse.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Methods
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Functions defined within an object that operate on the object\'s state and provide its behavior.

name: Network of Objects
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A design structure where objects interact with each other, forming a network rather than a hierarchical tree.

name: Statechart Formalism
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A modeling tool used to represent states and transitions in a system, particularly useful in object-oriented design.

name: Object Collaboration
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that emphasizes the interaction between objects in a system, crucial for designing loosely coupled architectures.

name: Object-Oriented Style
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural style that uses objects to represent data and behavior, promoting encapsulation and interaction.

name: Call-and-Return
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that structures programs as a series of calls to sub-programs, facilitating straightforward mapping to procedural languages.

name: Method
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A function defined within a class that describes the behavior of an object.

name: Statechart
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A design pattern used to model the states and transitions of an object, particularly useful in representing complex behaviors in systems.

label:LABEL: DesignPattern

name: Transition
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Component-Based Software Engineering (CBSE)

name: Software Component

name: Software Service

name: Reusable Software Blocks
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

name: Call-and-return architectural style
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural style where components communicate by calling each other and returning results.

name: Data-centred repository architectural style

name: Data-flow diagram (DFD)

name: Storyboard

source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Access Control Proxy
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A specific type of proxy that controls access rights to an object based on user roles.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Rapid Application Development (RAD)
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural approach that structures incremental development for faster delivery of applications.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Active User Involvement
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle emphasizing the necessity of user participation in the development process.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Empowered Teams
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that stresses the importance of team autonomy in decision-making during development.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Frequent Delivery of Products
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that prioritizes regular product increments over activity-based increments.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Iterative and Incremental Development
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that advocates for repeated cycles of development to refine and converge on accurate solutions.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: DSDM Process
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: A framework consisting of five phases for incremental software development, emphasizing collaboration and iterative design.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Feasibility Study
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: An initial phase in the DSDM process aimed at exploring possible architectural forms and delivering a feasibility report.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Functional Prototype
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A prototype created during the DSDM process to validate design decisions and gather user feedback.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Design Prototype
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A prototype that embodies the first real design decisions in the DSDM process, focusing on system architecture.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Must Have Requirements
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Fundamental requirements that are essential for the system\'s operability, impacting overall system reliability.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Should Have Requirements
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Important requirements that enhance system functionality but can be deferred, affecting maintainability.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Could Have Requirements
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Desirable but non-essential requirements that can be omitted in the current deliverable, impacting scalability.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Design Anti-Patterns
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: Commonly recognized poor design practices that can lead to suboptimal software architecture and implementation.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Code Smells
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: Indicators of potential issues in code that may suggest deeper design problems.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Broker Pattern

source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Pattern Decay
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: The deterioration of a design pattern\'s effectiveness due to changes in the objects involved.

name: Grime and Rot
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Concepts describing the corruption of a pattern that can occur when changes are made to the objects involved.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: God Class
label:LABEL: DesignPattern

source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Data Class
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A class that contains data fields and methods for accessing them but lacks a behavioral role, weakening object-oriented structures.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Design Patterns Vocabulary
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: The importance of acquiring a vocabulary of design patterns to effectively recognize and apply them.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Problem Specification
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: The process of clearly defining the problem and its sub-problems before selecting a design pattern.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Pattern Classification
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: Classifying problems and patterns to identify suitable design solutions.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Design Trade-offs
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: Assessing the benefits and liabilities of using a particular design pattern.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Component-Based Development
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that emphasizes the design and construction of software systems using reusable components.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Modular Implementation
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Event-Driven Control
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural style where the flow of the program is determined by events such as user actions or sensor outputs.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: ConcreteFactory2

description: An interface that defines the operations for products created by the Abstract Factory.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: ProductA1
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A concrete product created by ConcreteFactory1 that conforms to AbstractProductA.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: ProductA2
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A concrete product created by ConcreteFactory2 that conforms to AbstractProductA.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Component-Based Software Engineering
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that emphasizes the design and development of software systems using reusable components.

name: JavaBeans

name: Horizontal Integration

name: Vertical Integration

name: postconditions

name: Component Software
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that emphasizes the use of reusable software components.
source: Software Design – Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Duplication

description: A common code smell that indicates a need for refactoring to improve maintainability.

name: Design Review

name: Software Metrics

description: Quantitative measures used to assess the quality of software, including maintainability and performance.

name: Object-Oriented Metrics
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Metrics specifically designed to evaluate object-oriented software, linking design to quality attributes.

name: UML Notations
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A standardized modeling language used to visualize the design of a system, often used in software engineering.

name: Antipatterns
label:LABEL: DesignPattern

name: UML (Unified Modeling Language)
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A standardized modeling language used to visualize the design of a system.

name: Efficiency

name: layered
label:LABEL: ArchPattern

name: factory

name: Behavioral Pattern

label:LABEL: DesignPattern

label:LABEL: DesignPattern

label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

name: incremental development

name: Structural Pattern
label:LABEL: DesignPattern

name: Event-Driven
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural style that promotes the production, detection, consumption of, and reaction to events.

label:LABEL: QualityAttribute

label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

label:LABEL: QualityAttribute

name: System Architecture

name: Integration and Configuration
label:LABEL: ArchPattern

name: Service-Oriented Systems
label:LABEL: ArchPattern

name: Database Design
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Task Card

name: Plan-Driven Development
label:LABEL: ArchPattern

name: Design and Implementation
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Scenario

name: Requirement

name: Structured Natural Language

name: Product Requirements

name: incremental delivery

name: Card Reader Requirement

name: Graphical Model

name: Tabular Specification

name: Requirements Management

name: Model-Driven Engineering
label:LABEL: DDDConcept

name: Behavioral Perspective

name: Interaction Perspective

description: A viewpoint in system modeling that focuses on the interactions between a system and its environment.

name: External Perspective

name: State Model

name: Superstate

name: UML State Diagram

name: UML Activity Diagram
label:LABEL: DesignPattern

name: UML Component Diagram

label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Authentication and Authorization
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Design patterns that manage user identity verification and access control in secure systems.

name: Core Business Logic

name: Version-Controlled Environment
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Blackboard Model

name: Model-Driven Architecture

name: Architecture in the Large

name: Stakeholder Communication
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: An advantage of explicitly designing and documenting software architecture to facilitate discussions among stakeholders.

name: System Analysis
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: The process of analyzing the system architecture to ensure it meets critical requirements.

name: Large-scale Reuse
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: The benefit of having a compact architectural model that describes system organization and component interoperation.

name: State Diagram
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A diagram that shows transitions from state to state based on input events.

name: Logical View
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Represents key abstractions in the system as objects or object classes, linking system requirements to entities.

name: Process View
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Illustrates how the system is composed of interacting processes at runtime, useful for assessing non-functional characteristics like performance.

name: Development View
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Shows the decomposition of software into components for development, aiding software managers and programmers.

name: Physical View
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Displays system hardware and distribution of software components across processors, useful for system deployment planning.

name: Conceptual View
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An abstract view of the system that helps in decomposing high-level requirements and informs architectural decision making.

name: Software Reuse
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: The practice of using existing software components to build new systems, enhancing efficiency and reducing costs.

name: Configuration Management
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A discipline in software engineering that focuses on maintaining the consistency of a product\'s performance and functional attributes.

name: Dynamic Object Creation

description: A pattern that involves creating objects at runtime based on class definitions, enhancing flexibility in object-oriented design.

name: State Machine Model

name: Subsystem Model

name: SatComms

name: Validation Testing

name: Weather Station Object

name: UML Design Models

name: Testing

name: Program Understanding

name: Diversity
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

name: Redundant Components

name: Software Diversity
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute

name: Validation Activities

name: Redundant Servers
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Fault-Finding Techniques
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Verification and Validation
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

name: System-Level View

label:LABEL: CodeStructure

label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Formal Specification

label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Embedded Systems
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: User Interaction Patterns

name: Good programming practices
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

description: An architectural style where the system monitors its own operation and takes action if problems are detected, enhancing reliability.

name: Diversity in Hardware and Software
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A design principle that advocates using diverse hardware and software to reduce the probability of common faults affecting system operations.

label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: An approach that considers both social and technical aspects of a system in its design and operation.

name: Software diversity
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: A quality attribute that emphasizes the use of diverse implementations to reduce common mode failures in fault-tolerant systems.

description: A reliability metric that indicates the likelihood of a system failing when requested to perform a function.

name: Operational Profile

name: Formal Methods
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: Techniques used for mathematically analyzing and verifying system specifications.

name: Diversity in Software Processes
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: Utilizing different approaches or technologies to achieve the same functionality to enhance dependability.

name: Reliability Growth Model

label:LABEL: QualityAttribute

name: Platform-level Protection

description: The top layer of protection that controls access to the platform on which the system runs, including user authentication.

name: Application-level Protection
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The layer of protection built into the application that manages user access and authorization for actions on data.

name: Security Testing
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: The process of assessing a system\'s ability to resist attacks and vulnerabilities.

name: Input Validation
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A design pattern that ensures inputs are checked against expected formats to prevent vulnerabilities like SQL injection.

name: Security Risk Management
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Involves assessing potential losses from attacks and deriving security requirements to mitigate these risks.

name: Secure Systems Architecture
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Involves organizing system structure to protect key assets and minimize losses from attacks.

name: Penetration Testing
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: A method of testing that simulates attacks on a system to evaluate its security and identify vulnerabilities.

name: Experience-based Testing
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: A testing approach that relies on the knowledge and experience of the testing team to identify potential security vulnerabilities.

name: Buffer Overflow
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute

name: Security Checklist
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A structured list of security-related checks to ensure that an application adheres to security guidelines.

name: Access Permissions
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Rules that determine who can access certain files or resources within an application, crucial for maintaining security.

name: Strong Passwords
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Passwords that meet complexity requirements to enhance security against unauthorized access.

name: Reliability Engineering
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Focuses on ensuring that systems do not fail, emphasizing the importance of minimizing faults.

name: Cyberattack
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: An external event that can lead to system failure, highlighting the need for security measures.

name: System Recovery Features
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: System features designed to maintain critical services and recover from failures.

name: Emergency Mode
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A design pattern that allows systems to operate under special conditions where normal checks are bypassed, logging actions for audit purposes.

name: Authentication and Encryption
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Security measures that protect confidential data from unauthorized access, critical for maintaining system integrity.

name: Access Rights Management
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A code structure that defines how user permissions are managed and enforced within a system.

name: Audit Trail
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A code structure that logs actions taken by users, providing a record for accountability and security audits.

name: Recovery Procedures
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Defined steps to restore a system to its normal operating state after a failure.

name: Attack Resistance
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: The capability of a system to withstand attacks and maintain functionality.

name: System Repair
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Refers to the processes involved in restoring a system to operational status after a failure.

name: Software and Data Restoration
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Processes involved in recovering software and data after a cyber incident.

name: Usability vs Security Trade-offs
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: The balance between making systems user-friendly and ensuring they are secure.

name: Redundancy and Diversity
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple

name: Defensive Layers

name: Approval Procedure
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Conflict Alert Warning

name: Critical Services

name: Redundancy Strategy

name: user interface design

name: MOT Certificate System
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Records all roadworthiness certificates issued by licensed testing agencies.

name: Systems of Systems Architecture
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that focuses on the integration and interoperability of multiple independent systems to form a cohesive system.

name: Interfaces
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Defined points of interaction between system components that facilitate communication and interoperability.

name: Observe and React
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern used for monitoring sensors and reacting to events in real-time systems.

name: Environmental Control
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that involves sensors and actuators to control environmental changes based on detected conditions.

name: System Selection
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The process of evaluating and choosing systems for inclusion in a system of systems, based on their capabilities and requirements.

name: Conceptual Design
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The activity of creating a high-level vision for a system, defining essential requirements, and identifying constraints.

name: Systems of Systems Engineering
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that focuses on the integration and management of multiple independent systems to achieve a common goal.

name: Trading System Pattern
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern for trading systems that operates without a central authority, allowing decentralized transactions.

name: Real-time System
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern designed to respond to external events in a timely manner, crucial for embedded systems.

name: Power Conservation
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A design principle that emphasizes minimizing power consumption in embedded systems to prolong battery life.

name: Direct Hardware Interaction
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A code structure that allows software to interact directly with hardware components, necessary for embedded systems without separate device drivers.

name: Nonpreemptive Scheduling
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A scheduling strategy where a process runs to completion or until blocked, relevant in real-time systems for managing process execution.

name: Preemptive Scheduling
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A scheduling strategy that allows higher priority processes to interrupt lower priority ones, crucial for real-time systems to meet timing requirements.

name: Periodic Process
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A process that runs at regular intervals, essential for maintaining timing requirements in real-time systems.

name: Repairability
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Reflects how easy it is to fix a problem with the system once it has been discovered.

name: Observe and React Pattern
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that facilitates the observation of events and the reaction to those events, commonly used in real-time systems.

name: Environmental Control Pattern
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern used in control systems that analyzes sensor data to control actuators based on environmental stimuli.

name: Anti-skid Feature
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A design pattern implemented in automotive systems to prevent skidding by controlling brake signals based on wheel sensor data.

name: Monitor Process
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A code structure responsible for monitoring the state of sensors and actuators in a control system.

name: Display Process
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A code structure that handles the display of sensor values and actuator states in a control system.

name: Fuel Delivery System
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: A specific domain model representing the operations and states of a fuel delivery system, including state transitions.

name: Waiting State
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: A specific state in the state model where the system idles when not in operation.

name: Validating State
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: A state in the fuel delivery system where the credit card is validated before proceeding with the transaction.

name: Delivering State
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: A state in the fuel delivery system where fuel is actively being delivered to the customer.

name: Maintaining State
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: An attribute of the system that ensures it can be maintained and operated without human intervention.

name: Real-time Operating System
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An operating system designed to serve real-time application requests, managing processes and resources efficiently.

name: Responsiveness
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: A critical quality attribute in real-time systems that ensures timely processing and response to stimuli.

name: Model-Driven Development
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: An approach to software development that focuses on creating and exploiting domain models.

name: State-based Modeling
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A design pattern that uses states to model the behavior of systems, particularly useful in embedded systems.

name: Application Composition Model
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Models the effort required to develop systems created from reusable components, scripting, or database programming.

name: Early Design Model
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Used during early stages of system design to estimate effort based on established requirements.

name: Reuse Model
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Computes the effort required to integrate reusable components or automatically generated code.

name: Post-Architecture Model
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Provides accurate software size estimates after system architecture has been designed.

name: Function Points
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: A language-independent way of quantifying program functionality based on external inputs and outputs.

name: Memory Constraint
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Refers to the limitations on memory usage that can impact performance and scalability of a software system.

name: Quality Culture
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: An organizational commitment to quality in software development, emphasizing responsibility and continuous improvement.

name: AAM
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Adaptation Adjustment Multiplier that reflects the additional effort required to reuse components.

name: AA
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Assessment factor representing the effort involved in deciding whether or not to reuse components.

name: SU
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Understanding component representing the costs of understanding the code to be reused.

name: AAF
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Adaptation component representing the costs of making changes to the reused code.

name: COCOMO II
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: A model used for estimating the effort required for software development, particularly in the context of reuse.

name: CK Metrics Suite
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A suite of object-oriented metrics proposed by Chidamber and Kemerer to measure various aspects of software quality.

name: System Complexity
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: A measure of how complicated a software system is, which can affect maintainability and understandability.

name: Component Measurement Process
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A structured approach to analyze and assess the quality of individual software components using various metrics.

name: Static Metrics
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Metrics collected from representations of the system, such as design or documentation, to assess quality attributes.

name: Software Measurement
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The process of quantifying attributes of a software system to assess its quality and effectiveness.

name: Change Management
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: The process of managing changes to the software system, including bug fixes and feature requests.

name: System Testing Phase
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A distinct phase in the software development lifecycle focused on testing the system for bugs and performance issues.

name: Development Phase
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The initial phase of software development where new functionality is added and changes are managed.

name: Codeline
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A sequence of versions of source code, with later versions derived from earlier versions, typically applied to components of systems.

name: Baseline
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A definition of a specific system that specifies the component versions included and identifies libraries and configuration files.

name: Version Control System
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A system that manages changes to source code over time, allowing multiple developers to work on the same codebase without conflicts.

name: Centralized Version Control System
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A version control system where a single master repository maintains all versions of the software components.

name: Distributed Version Control System
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A version control system where multiple versions of the component repository exist simultaneously.

name: Workspace
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A developer\'s local environment where they can work on code independently before integrating changes back to the main repository.

name: Clone
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A copy of the repository that allows developers to work on their own version of the codebase without affecting the original.

name: Check-in
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: The process of submitting changes made in a workspace back to the repository, creating a new version of the component.

name: Check-out
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: The action of retrieving a component from the repository to work on it in a private workspace.

name: component-based software engineering (CBSE)
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: The development of software by composing independent, deployable software components.

name: dependability
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: An aggregate property reflecting safety, reliability, availability, security, and resilience of a system.

name: Checksum Management
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A method for uniquely identifying source code files and their corresponding object code files using checksums, allowing for parallel compilation and version management.

name: Source Code File
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The original code written by developers, which is compiled into object code.

name: Object Code File
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The compiled version of the source code file, generated by the compiler.

name: Merging
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A design pattern in version control that combines changes from different branches into a single version.

name: Delta Storage
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A method of storing only the differences between versions to minimize disk space usage.

name: Definitive Project Repository
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The main repository that holds the final and approved versions of the project components.

name: Build Server
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A server that automates the process of building and testing software components, facilitating continuous integration.

name: Version Management System
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A system that manages changes to source code over time, allowing multiple developers to collaborate effectively.

name: Reference Architecture
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: A generic architecture that informs designers about the general structure of a class of systems.

name: Derivation History
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A record of changes made to a software component, often maintained in comments within the source code.

name: state diagram
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A UML diagram type that shows the states of a system and the events that trigger a transition from one state to another.

name: transaction
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: A unit of interaction with a computer system, fundamental for recovery, consistency, and concurrency.

name: transaction processing system
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: A system that ensures transactions are processed independently and atomically, maintaining data integrity.

name: Unified Modeling Language (UML)
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A standardized modeling language used to specify, visualize, and document software system designs.

name: structured method
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A method of software design that defines system models, rules, guidelines, and processes for development.

name: model-driven development
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: An approach to software engineering that focuses on creating and exploiting domain models.

name: operational profile
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: A set of artificial system inputs used to reflect the operational behavior of a system.

name: aggregation
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: A design concept in Domain-Driven Design that groups related entities and value objects into a single unit.

name: Repository Architectural Pattern
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: A pattern that abstracts data access and provides a collection-like interface for accessing domain objects.

name: Decorator pattern
label:LABEL: DesignPattern
description: A structural design pattern that allows behavior to be added to individual objects, either statically or dynamically, without affecting the behavior of other objects from the same class.

name: event-driven architecture
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern where the flow of the program is determined by events.
source: The Architecture of Open Source Applications 2.pdf

name: Fault-Tolerant Architectures
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Architectural patterns designed to ensure system reliability and availability in the presence of faults.

name: Event-Driven Modeling
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural style that focuses on the production, detection, consumption of, and reaction to events.

name: service-oriented architectures (SOAs)
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that allows services to communicate over a network, promoting loose coupling and reusability.

name: service-to-service communication
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: A method of communication between services in a microservices architecture, often using REST or messaging protocols.

name: RESTful approach
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural style that uses HTTP requests to access and use data, following REST principles.

name: simple design
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that advocates for simplicity in design, making systems easier to understand and maintain.

name: software quality attributes
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Characteristics that affect the quality of software, including maintainability, performance, and security.

name: Divergent Thinking
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A type of thinking that generates multiple possible solutions to a problem.
source: Software Engineering Design- Theory and Practice.pdf

name: Key Tasks in Architectural Design
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: Essential activities that guide the architectural design process, ensuring alignment with stakeholder needs.
source: Software Engineering Design- Theory and Practice.pdf

name: Impact of Architectural Decisions
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: The consequences of architectural choices on various aspects of the software system, including performance and maintainability.
source: Software Engineering Design- Theory and Practice.pdf

name: Common Coupling
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A type of coupling based on shared access to a common data area, such as global variables.
source: Software Engineering Design- Theory and Practice.pdf

name: Instantiation

description: The process of creating an instance of a class in memory during program execution.

name: Stereotype
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: A mechanism in UML to extend the semantics of classes, providing additional context such as <<interface>>.

name: Provided Interface

name: Required Interface

description: Diagrams that capture and specify static elements and their interrelationships in a software system.

name: Behavioral Diagrams
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: Diagrams that capture and specify the dynamic behavior and complexities of software systems.

label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: ClientCollectionSystem.exe
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: ServerMonitorSystem

name: Communication Diagram

name: Stakeholders\' Concerns
label:LABEL: DDDConcept
description: High-level information about desired characteristics of the software system, influencing architectural design.

name: Configuration Control

name: File System Organization
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Interface Definition
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Stable Interfaces

name: Messaging Structures

name: Quality Properties

name: Simulation Component

name: Completeness

description: A principle emphasizing the importance of specifying all necessary information in requirements to ensure correct functionality.

name: Attainability
label:LABEL: DesignPrinciple
description: A principle that focuses on ensuring requirements are realistic and achievable within given constraints.

name: Connector
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural entity that abstracts the complexities of interactions between components, facilitating communication in a modular architecture.

name: Single-Processor System

label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: MessageStatistics
label:LABEL: CodeStructure

name: Active Class

name: Logical Architecture
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The structure of software systems that includes system decomposition into logical components.

name: Components and Interfaces
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Essential elements that define the responsibilities and interactions within a software system.

name: Blackboard Pattern
label:LABEL: ArchPattern

name: Blackboard Architectural Pattern
label:LABEL: ArchPattern

name: Agent Component
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: Specialized components that independently contribute to the solution of a problem within the blackboard pattern.

name: Broker Architectural Pattern
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that decouples clients and servers, allowing for flexible communication and service requests.
source: Software Engineering Design- Theory and Practice.pdf

name: DvrServerProxy
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: A component that interfaces with the DvrSystem to relay client requests and prepare responses.

name: Client-Server Architectural Pattern

name: Main Program and Subroutine Architectural Pattern
label:LABEL: ArchPattern
description: An architectural pattern that organizes a system into a main program and subroutines, facilitating structured decomposition and component management.

name: Layered Architectural Pattern
label:LABEL: ArchPattern

name: Quality Properties of Main Program and Subroutine Pattern
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: Quality attributes associated with the main program and subroutine architectural pattern, including maintainability and reusability.

name: Document-View Architecture

name: Process-Abstraction-Controller (PAC)

name: DataSource

name: Quality Framework
label:LABEL: QualityAttribute
description: A set of quality attributes that guide the design and construction of software systems, such as performance and usability.

name: Construction Phase
label:LABEL: CodeStructure
description: The phase in software development where the actual coding occurs, relying on the detailed designs created earlier.

name: External Interface Design

name: Internal Interface Design

name: TerrestrialCharacter

name: Type Names
